headline: Half of Ohio National Guard members deployed to COVID-overwhelmed hospitals return home
author: Titus Wu
sentences:
New dashboard launches
Ohio will also launch a new dashboard next week connecting Ohioans and Ohio health care providers on where non-vaccine treatments for COVID-19 are available, such as oral treatments.

In addition to helping take care of patients, members helped set up and conduct testing sites near hospitals to reduce pressure on emergency rooms, which were flooded with people seeking COVID-19 tests.
Titus Wu is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.
On Tuesday, there were just 1,200 Guard members assisting 28 hospitals and 13 testing centers, said Dr. Bruce Vanderhoff, head of the Ohio Department of Health, on Thursday.
"While the National Guard may be reducing its presence... it's certainly not the time to let our guard down," said Vanderhoff, who still urged people to get vaccinated.
But Vanderhoff said there are still some parts of southern Ohio that have yet to see a sharp decline like other parts of the state.
The decline in COVID-19 cases in Ohio has been dramatic, and in some areas of the state in the northeast, accelerated, he said.

Hospitalizations continue to decrease daily in all parts of the state, with 2,863 hospitalizations as of Wednesday.
The number of daily reported cases in Ohio has seen a significant drop, staying below the 10,000 mark this month.
There has been an 18% decline in hospitalization numbers for just the last week, Vanderhoff said.
Hospital leaders over the past month have praised the National Guard for its help.
